hints_html:
The formula for the limit of the Rieman sum is

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{N\rightarrow \infty}\sum_{k=1}^N\left(\frac{b-a}{N}\right)\cdot f\left(a+\frac{k(b-a)}{N}\right) = \int_a^bf(x)dx.\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
The formula for the limit of the Rieman sum is

:<math> \lim_{N\rightarrow \infty}\sum_{k=1}^N\left(\frac{b-a}{N}\right)\cdot f\left(a+\frac{k(b-a)}{N}\right) = \int_a^bf(x)dx.</math>
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
As we see in the formula for the limit of the Riemann sum

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{N\rightarrow \infty}\sum_{k=1}^N\left(\frac{b-a}{N}\right)\cdot f\left(a+\frac{k(b-a)}{N}\right) = \int_a^bf(x)dx\end{aligned}\]

the factor that is devided by \(N\), must be \(b-a\). So, we know that \(b-a = 3\).

Now we search for the variable

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x_k=a+\frac{k(b-a)}{N} = a+\frac{3k}{N}.\end{aligned}\]

The only term, that matches this expression is

\[\begin{aligned} -2+\frac{3k}{N}\end{aligned}\]

and thus a must be equal to -2. With 3=b-a = b+2 we find that b=1.

The last thing is to find the function f. From the formula of the limit of the Riemann sum we know that

\[\begin{aligned} f\left(a+\frac{k(b-a)}{N}\right) = \left[\left(a + \frac{k(b-a)}{N}\right)^3-1\right],\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} f\left(-2+\frac{3k}{N}\right) = \left(-2 + \frac{3k}{N}\right)^3-1,\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = x^3-1.\end{aligned}\]

So the answer is (b),

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{N\rightarrow \infty}\sum_{k=1}^N\left(\frac{3}{N}\right)\cdot \left[\left(-2\frac{k3}{N}\right)^3-1\right] = \int_{-2}^1(x^3-1)dx.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
As we see in the formula for the limit of the Riemann sum

:<math> \lim_{N\rightarrow \infty}\sum_{k=1}^N\left(\frac{b-a}{N}\right)\cdot f\left(a+\frac{k(b-a)}{N}\right) = \int_a^bf(x)dx</math>

the factor that is devided by <math>\ N </math>, must be <math>\  b-a </math>. So, we know that <math>\ b-a = 3 </math>.


Now we search for the variable

:<math> \displaystyle x_k=a+\frac{k(b-a)}{N} = a+\frac{3k}{N}. </math>

The only term, that matches this expression is

:<math>\ -2+\frac{3k}{N}  </math>

and thus ''a'' must be equal to ''-2''. With ''3=b-a = b+2'' we find that ''b=1''.

The last thing is to find the function ''f''. From the formula of the limit of the Riemann sum we know that

:<math> f\left(a+\frac{k(b-a)}{N}\right) = \left[\left(a + \frac{k(b-a)}{N}\right)^3-1\right],</math>

:<math> f\left(-2+\frac{3k}{N}\right) = \left(-2 + \frac{3k}{N}\right)^3-1,</math>

:<math> \ f(x) = x^3-1.</math>

So the answer is '''(b)''',

:<math>\lim_{N\rightarrow \infty}\sum_{k=1}^N\left(\frac{3}{N}\right)\cdot \left[\left(-2\frac{k3}{N}\right)^3-1\right] = \int_{-2}^1(x^3-1)dx.</math>
statement_html:
Multiple choice question: Select ONE correct answer. You will not be graded for any work.

Which of these integrals does the sum

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^N \left(\frac3{N}\right) \left[\left(-2+\frac{3k}{N}\right)^3-1\right]\end{aligned}\]

approximate as \(N \rightarrow \infty\)?

(a) \(\int_0^3 x^3\,dx\)

(b) \(\int_{-2}^1 (x^3-1)\,dx\)

(c) \(\int_0^3 (x^3-2)\,dx\)

(d) \(\int_{-2}^1 x^3\,dx\)

(e) \(\int_0^1 (x-2)^3\,dx\)
statement_latex:
\emph{Multiple choice question: Select ONE correct answer. You will not
be graded for any work.}

Which of these integrals does the sum

\begin{align*}
\sum_{k=1}^N \left(\frac3{N}\right) \left[\left(-2+\frac{3k}{N}\right)^3-1\right]
\end{align*}

approximate as $N \rightarrow \infty$?

(a) $\int_0^3 x^3\,dx$

(b) $\int_{-2}^1 (x^3-1)\,dx$

(c) $\int_0^3 (x^3-2)\,dx$

(d) $\int_{-2}^1 x^3\,dx$

(e) $\int_0^1 (x-2)^3\,dx$
